title: STUDY THEME,  The Humanity of Jesus. Part 4
devotional:
Paul goes onto say that Jesus made himself nothing. Jesus was prepared to empty himself. The Greek verb kenaō, used for "emptied himself" literally means, "to make empty,”

This phrase has caused much debate, as to what Jesus emptied himself of. I don’t think that is the right question to ask. I think the best way to understand the phrase is to see it as a summation of Jesus’ way of living. The point Paul wants to make is that Jesus lived a poured-out life. Paul is not saying that Jesus poured something out of himself, no, rather he poured out himself.

If we feel that we need to be the centre of our worlds, if we think that life is all about having our needs being met, then we are becoming less than human. There is something built in all of us that requires us to embrace insignificance, we have been created to live humble lives that do not find significance or value in reputation, position or power.

Humility could be defined as, ‘freedom from any need to impress, or to have your needs/wants met because you are living a life of contentment and complete self acceptance because of the grace of God.’ There is real freedom in not being the centre of the universe.

In coming to earth and making himself of no reputation, Jesus was teaching us a new way to think, he was bringing a new world view, a different way to live. He was teaching us that having a humble attitude that is not in pursuit of reputation, power or position, rather it is to discover what it really means to be human. We all struggle with pride; we all want to be thought of better than we really are. But pride is the root of all sin, and has the power to dehumanise us.

To become more like Jesus is to become truly human. Our humanity is the highest expression of God’s creative power because He made man in his own image.

Being human is a wonderful thing, and as we fully grasp this, we will not say ‘we are only human’ again. It will be something that we will delight in rather than get annoyed at. Our humanity is something to be celebrated.
prayer: Prayer Father, teach me how to live a ‘poured out life.’
